abstract.p: Mika Hakkinen wins Belgian Grand Prix auto race; table (S)

block.p: Mika Hakkinen balanced one big mistake with one brilliant move yesterday as he won his first Belgian Grand Prix and lifted himself one step closer to his third consecutive Formula One drivers' title.
It was a suspenseful race in which Michael Schumacher, Hakkinen's closest rival in the title race, drove equally brilliantly in his Ferrari.
Mika Hakkinen balanced one big mistake with one brilliant move yesterday as he won his first Belgian Grand Prix and lifted himself one step closer to his third consecutive Formula One drivers' title.
It was a suspenseful race in which Michael Schumacher, Hakkinen's closest rival in the title race, drove equally brilliantly in his Ferrari.

Hakkinen, driving a McLaren, started from the pole and led for the first 12 laps before spinning out on Lap 13 and handing the lead to Schumacher. Hakkinen retook the lead a few laps from the end in a brilliant maneuver that even Schumacher applauded. Hakkinen won by 1.1 seconds, averaging 129.458 miles an hour.
Hakkinen leads Schumacher, 74 points to 68, with four races left.
